controller
Class GestureController

java.lang.Object
  controller.GestureController
All Implemented Interfaces:
xmlGestureParser<GestureController>, java.io.Serializable
Direct Known Subclasses:
GestureRecord
public class GestureController
extends java.lang.Object
implements xmlGestureParser<GestureController>, java.io.Serializable

A class to create and recognize simple gestures using the relationship between two joints provided by SimpleOpenNI. Gestures are recognized by detecting a series of steps that form the gesture. The steps are composed of two joints and relative position of the two focus joints. A step may be declared to be consecutive with the next declared step so that the two must be done at the same time, all consecutive steps appearing in sequence should have unique joint pairs or it will not be possible to complete the gesture. If a step is declared concurrent there must be a step following it. Gestures may be further constrained by the addition of constant constraints that must be met at every step or the gesture will be considered failed. Constant constraints are not required to declare a relationship for all three axes, declaring an axis to be null will disregard that axis while calculating if the constraint is upheld. An instance of this class should be used for each individual gesture. Bugs: Currently does NOT work with multiple users. Probably some with relation to concurrent and constant constraints not much testing has been done

Author:
Levi Lindsley
See Also:
Serialized Form

Epsilon

private static java.lang.Double Epsilon
Epsilon used to widen zero, modifying this will make zero have a larger range and thus be easier to hit but will decrease the sensitivity of noting when joints are not aligned It may be beneficial to split this into an x,y,z epsilon calculation complexity would increase but accuracy of gesture recognition may increase as a result Static across all GestureControllers change with caution.

isComplete

public boolean isComplete(SimpleOpenNI.SimpleOpenNI context,
                          int user)
This function should be called to check for gesture completion and to update the gesture. Checks if the gesture designated is complete or not. If it is not complete then the skeletal model from context is checked against a the current step of the gesture if the skeletal model matches then the step is incremented. If the retrieved skeletal position is between the current point and the previous competed point for the joint pair then the gesture is incremented or reset it hits a 'holding pattern' waiting for success or failure. If the gesture does not match either of the previous two conditions then it is assumed that the gesture failed and is reset accordingly.

Parameters:
context - : A SimpleOpenNI instance
user - : Id for users to check skeleton
Returns:
True if gesture is compete. Gesture is reset if complete. Gesture is incremented if not complete.

isComplete

public boolean isComplete(SimpleOpenNI.SimpleOpenNI context,

reset

public void reset()
Manually restart the gesture may be useful to impose other restrictions on the gesture that the controller does not account for such as being within a bounding box or holding an object

comp

protected static int comp(double x,
                          double x2)
Compares to floating point values taking Epsilon into account for equality. Returns the relationship proper between x and x2 (x {=, <, >} x2). This function may be modified to get range relation instead of relationship.

Parameters:
x - : A floating point value to be compared
x2 - : A floating point value to compare against
Returns:
0 : values were within the range given by Epsilon 1 : x > (x2+Epsilon) -1 : x < (x2-Epsilon)

angle

private static int angle(float alphaX,
                         float alphaY,
                         float betaX,
                         float betaY)
Calculates the angle between the two given points given by forming a triangle with the vertices alpha,beta,gamma where gammaX = alphaX and gammaY = betaY. The angle retrieved is sin(theta) Due to the three dimensional nature of the input data and the two dimensional calculation used here the X and Y referrals may not be to X, Y in the standard plane but to a 2D plane in 3D space with 3D points flattened onto it.

Parameters:
alphaX - : X coordinate of point alpha
alphaY - : Y coordinate of point alpha
betaX - : X coordinate of point beta
betaY - : Y coordinate of point beta
Returns:
Angle between alpha and beta rounded to the nearest integer angle in degrees.
See Also:
Euclidean#planarAngle()

stepMatch

private boolean stepMatch(JointRelation V)
Check if the current step matches the relationship given by x,y,z perfectly

Parameters:
V - : PVector containing the relationship of the joints
Returns:
True if the V.x,V.y,and V.z all match the respective relationship given by the current step in the sequence

midMatch

private boolean midMatch(JointRelation V)
Checks to see if the given x,y,z relationships fall between the relationships given by the current step and the previous step. This is used to check if a gesture may have paused but not terminated such as the user is moving slow so they haven't made it to the next step but did not do anything wrong yet the controller just needs to wait on the user to finish the gesture.

Parameters:
V - : PVector containing the relationship of the joints
Returns:
True if the given relationships fall between the current and previous step.

chkCoord

private boolean chkCoord(int cur,
                         int val,
                         int prev)
Checks if val is between cur and prev, the bounds do not need to be in any order thus if prev > cur, cur > prev, or cur = prev this will still return the proper value

Parameters:
cur - : bounding value
val - : value to check
prev - : bounding value
Returns:
True if val is between cur and prev
See Also:
JointRelation.chkBounds(double, double, double)

reduce

private java.util.List<java.util.Vector<JointRelation>> reduce(int i,
                                                               boolean[] visit,
                                                               java.util.Vector<java.lang.Integer> index)
Iteratively walk through a vector following the prev link and create a list of maximum size of continuous points that are within epsilon of i

Parameters:
i - : Index of sequence to begin on
visit - : Shows which indexes have been visited
index - : An index of the positions in the returned list
Returns:
A list of the points that are within epsilon of sequence.get(i)

Null if i is outOfBounds or visit[i] is true
